children.name: meaning
children.definition: what a word, sign, or statement means: nghĩa
examples: This word ‘spring’ has several different meanings.
We convey meaning not only by our words but also by our actions.

children.name: have a meaning
examples: The same word may have several different meanings.

children.name: take on a meaning
children.definition: begin to have a new meaning
examples: The word ‘chaos’ has taken on a special scientific meaning.

children.name: understand the meaning
examples: The pictures help the children understand the meanings of the words.

children.name: know the meaning
examples: Do you know the meaning of the word ‘paraphrase’?

children.name: get sb’s meaning
children.definition: alsotake sb’s meaningBritish English
examples: (= understand what someone is saying in an indirect way )He’s not like other people, if you get my meaning.

children.name: grasp the meaning
children.definition: begin to understand the meaning
examples: She suddenly grasped the meaning of his frantic gestures.

children.name: carry meaning
children.definition: alsobear a meaningformal
examples: (= have a meaning )In conversation, even a pause may carry meaning.

children.name: convey meaning
children.definition: express a meaning
examples: the use of hand signals to convey meaning

children.name: precise/specific/exact
examples: The term ‘stress’ has a precise meaning to an engineer.

children.name: a hidden meaning
examples: She felt there was a hidden meaning behind his words.

children.name: a double meaning
children.definition: two meanings at the same time
examples: Everything he said had a double meaning.

children.name: the literal meaning
examples: The literal meaning of ‘telephone’ is ‘far-away sound’.

children.name: the ordinary meaning
examples: They are a 'nuisance' in the ordinary meaning, not the legal meaning, of that word.

children.name: the figurative/metaphorical meaning
children.definition: different from its usual or basic meaning
examples: The expression has a metaphorical meaning.

children.name: sb’s/sth’s true meaning
examples: Children understand the true meaning of these words.

children.name: a symbolic meaning
children.definition: representing an idea
examples: Colours often have symbolic meanings; for example, black signifies grief in Western cultures.

children.name: meaning of
examples: I don’t know the precise meaning of the word ‘gleaned’.

children.name: sense
children.definition: oneof the possible meanings of a word or phrase that has several meanings: nghĩa

children.name: sense of
examples: In the dictionary the different senses of each word are marked by numbers.

children.name: in a sense
examples: They are not immigrants, at least notinany sense that I understand.
The packaging is green - in both senses of the word (= it is green in colour and it is good for the environment) .

children.name: in its broadest/fullest sensein the most general meaning of the word
examples: I’m using the word ‘education’ in its broadest sense here.
Security definedin the broad/broadestsenseofthe term means getting at the root causes of trouble and helping to reduce regional conflicts.

children.name: make sense
examples: This passage doesn'tmake (any)sense (= the meaning is not clear) .

children.name: I've read the letter twice, but I can'tmake (any)senseofit (= I can't understand it)
significance
children.definition: the meaning of a word, sign, action etc, especially when this is not immediately clear: ý nghĩa
examples: significance of
the significance of the words that refer to the bread Christ shares with his disciples
full/real/true significance
Only later did we realize the true significance of his remark.
special significance
Nothing can be more exciting than the first time you receive red roses. They have special significance.

children.name: connotation
children.definition: a feeling or an idea that a word makes you think of that is not its actual meaning: nghĩa mở rộng
examples: ‘Bermuda’ with its connotations of fun and sun
positive/negative connotation
For most people ‘motherhood’ has a very positive connotation.

children.name: when sth has a meaning that is not directly stated
suggest
children.definition: if a statement, fact, event etc suggests that something is true, it seems to mean that it is true or could be true, but this is not directly stated:
examples: ▪ It is still not clear what these facts suggest -- perhaps a new strain of the virus, or a completely new virus.
suggest (that)
▪ All the evidence suggests that the problem has improved in recent years.
▪ The victim had marks on his neck which seemed to suggest he had been strangled.
suggestverb[ T ]SHOW/EXPRESS
to communicate or show an idea or feeling without stating it directly or giving proof
_[ + ( that ) ]There's no absolute proof, but all the evidence suggests(that)he's guilty.
_Are you suggesting(thatI look fat in these trousers?
_Something about his manner suggested a lack of interest in what we were doing.

children.name: imply
children.definition: if a statement, fact, event etc implies that something is true, it suggests very strongly that it is true:
examples: His criticisms implied a lack of confidence in my work.
implication[C or U] C2 a meaning that is not directly stated, but which seems to be intended: hàm ý, ngụ ý
He didn’t actually accuse me of stealing, but that was the implication.
implication that
Staff members were asked to work on Sundays, with the implication that they would lose their jobs if they refused.
From what she said, the implication was that they were splitting up.
by implicationthe intended meaning is that
The law bans organized protests and, by implication, any form of opposition.
She accused the party and, by implication, its leader too.

children.name: They are called ‘Supertrams’,the implication being that
children.definition: which is meant to suggest that
examples: they are more advanced than earlier models.

children.name: imply (that)
examples: The way he greeted the boys seemed to imply that he knew them quite well.
Just the fact that he’s written to you implies he likes you.
I'm not implying anything about your cooking, but could we eat out tonight?
I detected an impliedcriticismof the way he was treated.

children.name: say
children.definition: to say something in an indirect way - use this especially when you are saying what the real meaning of a statement is:
examples: ▪ What do you think the writer is saying in this story?

children.name: say (that)
examples: ▪ Are you saying I’m fat?
▪ So what you’re saying, Mr President, is that you don’t have a policy on this issue.

children.name: undertone
children.definition: a feeling or attitude that seems to be part of a statement, even though it is not directly stated: ngầm
examples: a story with racist undertones
undertone of
There was an unmistakable undertone of nationalist resentment in many of their remarks.

children.name: sb’s opinion about the meaning of sth
interpretation
children.definition: sb’s opinion about the probable meaning of a statement, result, someone’s actions etc: cách hiểu
examples: One possible interpretation is that they want you to resign.
literalinterpretation
It is difficult for many people to accept aliteralinterpretation of the Bible.
interpretation of
▪ the traditional interpretation of Marx’s opinions
be open to interpretationto be able to be interpreted in more than one way
The word ‘reasonable’ is vague and open to interpretation.
What exactly the author meant by that statement isopen to interpretation
put aninterpretation on(= explain )
It’s difficult toputan accurateinterpretation onthe survey results.

children.name: understanding
children.definition: someone’s opinion about the meaning of a piece of writing or an action, used especially when they realize that there are other possible meanings:

children.name: sb’s understanding (of sth)
examples: My understandingofthe agreement is that they will pay £50 000 over two years.
According to my understanding of the letter, it means something quite different.
That was not my understanding of the regulations, and I resent your accusation that I failed to follow them correctly.

children.name: reading
children.definition: sb’s opinion about the meaning of a statement, an event, or a situation after considering all the available information:

children.name: sb’s reading of sth
examples: What’s your reading of the latest trade figures?
My reading of the situation is that this conflict is likely to get worse over the next few months.

children.name: clear or not which meaning is intended
ambiguous
children.definition: sth that is ambiguous is unclear, confusing, or not certain, especially because it can be understood in more than one wayOPP unambiguous: lưỡng nghĩa
examples: The language in the Minister’s statement is highly ambiguous.
His role in the affair is ambiguous.

children.name: unambiguous
children.definition: a statement, instruction etc that is unambiguous is clear and easy to understand because it can only mean one thing
examples: —unambiguouslyadverb

children.name: definition
children.definition: a phrase or sentence that says exactly what a word, phrase, or idea means: định nghĩa
examples: a dictionary definition
definition of
There are many definitions of the word ‘feminism’.
sb’s definition of sth
Obviously your definition of ‘rich’ is very different from mine.
definition of sth as sth
the definition of God as infinite
verbs

children.name: clear/precise
examples: The head teacher gave us a precise definition of the school’s aims.

children.name: broad
children.definition: including a lot of general ideas
examples: This is a very broad definition of what poetry is.

children.name: narrow
children.definition: including only a few ideas
examples: Some psychiatrists still use a very narrow definition of mental illness.

children.name: the dictionary definition
examples: Some doctors don’t accept the dictionary definition of euthanasia, and want to create different categories of assisted death.

children.name: the legal definition of something
examples: What is the legal definition of manslaughter?

children.name: give a definition
examples: Can you give me a definition of 'psychology'?

children.name: extend/broaden/widen a definition
children.definition: make it include more ideas
examples: The new law has broadened the definition of terrorism.

children.name: define
children.definition: to explain the meaning of a word or phrase: định nghĩa
examples: Each of us might define the concept of freedom in a slightly different way.
I’ll now try to define the term ‘popular culture’.
Before I answer your question, could you define yourtermsa little more (= explain what you mean by the words you have used) ?

children.name: define sth as sth
examples: A budget is defined as ‘a plan of action expressed in money terms’.
Define precisely what you mean by ‘crime’.
The dictionary defines it as ‘a narrow passage’.

children.name: define sth loosely/broadlydefine something in a way that is not very exact
examples: Dietary fibre can be loosely defined as the cell-wall material of plants.
